body: This is an interesting problem. As long as you don't consider reflections, (I think) you can calculate long-wave and short-wave using LB/HB with the Gencumulativesky module.It is probably easier to do with grid points than it is with an image based simulation. You can separate the radiation reaching a point into long-wave and short-wave based on the spectral power distribution of the solar spectrum. I am attaching an image below. This is also available in a Tabular format in Table 1.3.1a in Solar Engineering of Thermal Processes by Duffie (4th Ed). [](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Solar_Spectrum.png) The area under the curve represents the total radiation. You can derive long-wave and short-wave components by multiplying the total radiation with the weighting factors corresponding to each component. (PS: Please cross-check with some scholarly articles before finalizing such an approach for any project/research)
